newsitem.title: CHINA: Shanghai soybean futures end up on short-covering.
newsitem.headline: Shanghai soybean futures end up on short-covering.

text.p: Shanghai soybean futures ended mostly up on Monday due to short-covering but potential for further rises is limited due to poor fundamentals, traders said.
The key November 1996 contract closed at 3,289 yuan ($396) per tonne, rising 19 yuan. It opened at an intra-day low of 3,275 and hit a high of 3,310.
January rose 39 to 3,249, March 41 to 3,290 and May fell 20 to 3,292. Combined volume fell to 18,700 tonnes from 21,200.
Traders said short-covering from retail investors pushed the prices up but poor fundamentals would limit further rises.
"Short-covering was responsible for today's rises," a trader said. "But over-supply of spot soybean will keep the contracts on a downward trend in the short term," he added.
Traders said soybean has fallen continuously over the past few weeks due to over-supply of spot soybeans.
"Technical charts indicate soybean is likely to test the key 3,200 yuan support level this week," a second trader said.
